reasoning: The critique targets a genuine, relevant vulnerability: the essay’s emphasis on “fragility” and many ways to lose most value could (if socially internalized) incentivize hyper-vigilance, decision paralysis, and empowerment of veto/arbiter institutions—undermining flourishing. However, this is not central to the essay’s main claim (that, conditional on survival and absent deliberate optimization, mostly-great futures are unlikely because the value target is narrow). The critique mostly shifts from the descriptive thesis (“target is narrow”) to a potential prescriptive/second-order consequence (“fussiness leads to paralysis”), which the essay can accommodate (it briefly flags meta-level perils and later separates ‘target narrow’ from ‘likely hit’). Strength is moderate: it raises a plausible mechanism (weaponized moral uncertainty; precautionary gridlock) but provides little argument that (a) society would adopt that extreme precautionary regime because of the thesis, or (b) such a regime is the dominant, robust equilibrium rather than one failure mode among many. Correctness is fairly high as a conditional possibility claim, though some asserted consequences (centralized sovereign adjudicators, stagnation) are speculative. Clarity is good and focused, with minimal dead weight, and it largely sticks to one issue (second-order/meta-catastrophe of precaution/paralysis). Overall, it’s a helpful caution but not a major refutation of the position.
title: Hyper-vigilant moral precaution risks paralysis and centralized veto power
